Similarly, the checklist approach to learning Excel does not at all mean that you have mastered either formulas or VBA. Rather than seeking to add yet another mediocre skill level, I suggest that you instead aspire to mastering formulas and VBA. Add another skill only if you need it for a project—and then start along the path of mastering it as well.I have a friend who likes to apply the concept of “infinite resistance” to his hobbies. He lifts weights, and each time he increases the amount he lifts, the number of repetitions he is capable of drops dramatically. Over many days of lifting, he can increase the number of reps until he reaches the mid twenties. At that point, he increases the weight, and the process begins anew.Let’s take a look at your level of expertise. How many functions do you feel comfortable building formulas with? Pick one of them. Could you dictate a formula using that function to a colleague to help him solve a problem? Do you know its strengths and weaknesses? Do you know how it behaves in an array formula as opposed to a regular formula? Do you know which error values it might return and why? Have you mastered its optional parameters? I’d be hard-pressed to say that you had mastered that particular function until you could give me good answers to those questions. And I would be reluctant to say that you had mastered formulas until you were comfortable with at least a hundred different functions at that level.VBA is the same. Sure, you can record a macro and edit it to do a simple formatting or data manipulation task. But do you know how and when to use class modules? API functions? Loan objects from VBScript (such as regular expressions or dictionary)? Are you comfortable building a powerful add-in for use by people with little Excel skill? Do you know how to tackle a project that will ultimately result in 50 pages of code? Do you do unit testing?The formula and VBA skills I mentioned aren’t something you can pick up after a few months of playing around. It takes years of intensive use before you become the person everybody goes to for Excel help where you work. And if you are that person, it will take even more years before you become the person answering the tough questions on Excel help forums. It isn’t that you can’t figure out the answers to the questions—it’s that other experts post great answers much faster. And if you do become one of the people who tackle a lot of forum questions, you will probably run into Excel MVPs with even higher skill levels. There will always be somebody better than you. Just like with weightlifting, each time you master skills at one level, infinite resistance means you find another level where you have just scratched the surface.
